project_metadata.paper_title: Barbarophonos: Language and Panhellenism in the Iliad
project_metadata.research_context: Philological analysis of linguistic diversity and unity in Homer's Iliad to investigate proto-Panhellenism in eighth-century BCE Greece. Examines how differential treatment of language between Akhaians and Trojan allies reveals an emerging but non-oppositional shared Greek identity.

evidence.evidence_text: Three passages in the Iliad directly address linguistic diversity: Il. 2.802-6, 2.867, and 4.433-38
evidence.verbatim_quote: Three passages in the Iliad directly address the speaking of different languages (Il. 2.802–6, 2.867, 4.433–38; Od. 19.172–77, each discussed below). In all three, Homer recognizes strangeness or diversity of speech among the ἐπίκουροι of the Trojans.

evidence.evidence_text: Il. 2.802-6: Iris warns Hektor that epikouroi speak different languages requiring each leader to command his own troops
evidence.verbatim_quote: The phrase ἄλλη δ' ἄλλων γλῶσσα πολυσπερέων ἀνθρώπων ('but there are different tongues among the wide-strewn human race') makes it clear that the ἐπίκουροι speak various mutually unintelligible languages; otherwise, there would be no need to dispatch each leader to command his own troops.

evidence.evidence_text: In Il. 2.802-6, linguistic variation follows polis and military contingent divisions
evidence.verbatim_quote: What is more, in this passage Hektor must dispatch each commander to array the residents of his own πόλις (πολιῆται). It is assumed that all members of a single πόλις community (and consequently the military contingent based upon it) speak the same language, but that language barriers may arise between πόλεις and their associated military bands.

evidence.evidence_text: Il. 2.867-69: Homer labels the Karians barbarophonos ('strange-speaking')
evidence.verbatim_quote: In this passage, Homer labels the Karians βαρβαρόφωνος ('barbarous-voiced' or 'strange-speaking') without further comment, before returning to the more usual practice in the Catalogues of describing the contingent's place of origin

evidence.evidence_text: This is the only use of a barbaros cognate in the Iliad and in Greek literature prior to the late sixth century BCE
evidence.verbatim_quote: This passage marks the only use of a βάρβαρος cognate or compound in the Iliad. Indeed, this is the only use of a βάρβαρος-cognate in Greek literature prior to the latter half of the sixth century B.C.E. (Anac. frag. 423 Page; see J. Hall 2002, 111–12).

evidence.evidence_text: The Trojan Catalogue appears geographically arranged with Karians among the most remote contingents
evidence.verbatim_quote: The idea of remoteness is reinforced by the fact that the Karians occur next-to-last in the Trojan Catalogue, which appears to be arranged in geographical order.

evidence.evidence_text: Il. 4.433-38: Three words for language emphasise Trojan linguistic diversity compared to bleating ewes
evidence.verbatim_quote: Three words, θρόος, γῆρυς, and γλῶσσα, used for language in two separate clauses, invoke the discord of the scene, emphasizing the fact that the languages spoken among the ἐπίκουροι are diverse, numerous, and—when considered in the context of Iliad 2.802–6, where interpreters prove necessary—mutually unintelligible.

evidence.evidence_text: Linguistic variation in Il. 4.438 depends upon place of origin: tongues mingled because troops summoned from many lands
evidence.verbatim_quote: just as language is subordinate to πόλις and military divisions in Iliad 2.802–6, linguistic variation here depends upon place of origin: γλῶσσα μέμικτο ('their tongue was mingled') because they were πολύκλητοι ('summoned from many lands').

evidence.evidence_text: Akhaians and Trojans communicate freely; no linguistic barrier between them
evidence.verbatim_quote: On the one hand, Akhaians and Trojans communicate freely with one another; no hard linguistic dividing line between Akhaians and others emerges over the course of the epic, nor does it appear that the later, categorical Greek-Barbarian dichotomy has yet emerged.

evidence.evidence_text: Linguistic diversity limited to Trojan epikouroi while absent from Akhaian forces
evidence.verbatim_quote: On the other hand, through poetic emphasis or suppression, linguistic diversity is limited to the Trojan ἐπίκουροι (allies or companions) defending the city, while it is absent from the Akhaian forces besieging Troy.

evidence.evidence_text: Od. 19.172-77: Krete described with mixed languages among five peoples
evidence.verbatim_quote: The languages spoken on the island are simply described as μεμιγμένη ('mingled' or 'mixed') using the same verb (μίγνυμι) employed in Iliad 4.438, where it invokes the cacophony of the Trojan host. Likewise, the phrase ἄλλη δ' ἄλλων γλῶσσα is repeated from Iliad 2.804

evidence.evidence_text: Groups traditionally considered Greek not distinguished from non-Greek on Krete
evidence.verbatim_quote: Groups traditionally considered Greek (Akhaians and Dorians) are not, however, distinguished from those who were not (Eteocretans, Kudones, Pelasgians); again, no rigid dichotomy emerges between Akhaians and non-Akhaians.

evidence.evidence_text: Hesiod's Theogony: Typhoeus produces divine and animal sounds but no human speech
evidence.verbatim_quote: Typhoeus produces no kind of human speech. The list of πανtoίην ὄπ' . . . ἀθέσφατον begins, somewhat incongruously... with ὥς τε θεοῖσι συνιέμεν ('[a sound] as if for the gods' understanding'). Hesiod then contrasts this divine 'language' with other πανtoίην ὄπ' . . . ἀθέσφατον: the sound of a bull, a lion, a pack of dogs, and ῥοίζεσχ' ('hissing')

evidence.evidence_text: Il. 1.403-4: Two names for Briareos/Aigaion - divine and human
evidence.verbatim_quote: Providing two names—one divine, the other human—both exemplifies the concern of Greek epic with the division between the human and the divine and offers the poet an opportunity to display his privileged knowledge of the names used by the gods.

evidence.evidence_text: Hymn to Delian Apollo 156-64: Delian maidens sing understood by all human languages
evidence.verbatim_quote: for the scene to be considered remarkable requires the imagined audience to come to the performance of the maidens speaking a multitude of languages. That the songs can be understood not only by Delian Greeks alone, but by all listeners, simultaneously, in all of their varied languages, ensures that the κλέος of the scene οὔποτ' ὀλεῖται.

evidence.evidence_text: Hymn to Aphrodite 111-16: Aphrodite explains she can speak Ankhises' language due to Trojan nurse
evidence.verbatim_quote: Just as interpreters were employed in the Iliad to facilitate communication between Trojans and ἐπίκουροι, here Aphrodite concocts an identity as a Phrygian princess who can only speak with Ankhises because she was brought up by a Trojan nurse, who taught her Ankhises' language.

evidence.evidence_text: Herodotus 8.144: Language as one of three central elements of Hellenic identity
evidence.verbatim_quote: Herodotus considers speaking a single tongue to be one of the three central elements of Hellenic identity, along with shared customs and a common religion. Implicit in Herodotus' observation is the belief that those who do not speak Greek differ fundamentally from those who do

evidence.evidence_text: Nagy argues poems stabilised by about 700 BCE due to wide diffusion limiting recomposition
evidence.verbatim_quote: I have settled on these dates not only because the epics appear, linguistically, to be earlier than other Greek poetry, but especially for the reason Gregory Nagy proposed: that by about 700 B.C.E. the poems were so widely diffused that opportunities for recomposition would have been limited by the expectations of a large, diverse, and informed audience.

evidence.evidence_text: Oral tradition retains institutions and relationships only when relevant to audience
evidence.verbatim_quote: By contrast, so long as it is evolving through recomposition, oral tradition only tends to retain information about institutions and relationships so long as they are immediately relevant to the poet's audience or relate directly to contemporary social structures.

evidence.evidence_text: Homer uses singular terms (γαῖα, λαός) for Akhaians indicating complex unity
evidence.verbatim_quote: Another indication of a complex unity among the Akhaians is that Homer consistently uses the singular γαῖα (or αἶα or πατρὶς γαῖα) to describe the place from which the Akhaian force was mustered and to which its members want to return. Similarly, the term λαός (people) is used in the singular when referring to the Akhaians as a whole

evidence.evidence_text: Cartledge: 'barbarian' never used as substantive or adjective in Homer
evidence.verbatim_quote: Cartledge (1993, 13) observes that 'Not once is "barbarian" used as either a substantive or adjective in all . . . of Homer.' Elsewhere, Cartledge adds that the single appearance of βαρβαρόφωνος lacks any negative overtones (Cartledge 1995, 78).

claims.claim_text: All instances of linguistic diversity in the Iliad occur among the Trojan epikouroi, not between Akhaians and non-Akhaians
claims.verbatim_quote: In all three, Homer recognizes strangeness or diversity of speech among the ἐπίκουροι of the Trojans... every reference to variation in language occurs within the Trojan sphere.

claims.claim_text: The Trojan epikouroi speak various mutually unintelligible languages requiring interpreters
claims.verbatim_quote: makes it clear that the ἐπίκουροι speak various mutually unintelligible languages; otherwise, there would be no need to dispatch each leader to command his own troops.

claims.claim_text: Language in the Iliad follows the contours of polis and military contingent rather than defining ethnic groups
claims.verbatim_quote: In this case, language does not define particular ethnic or socio-linguistic groups. Instead, linguistic variation among the ἐπίκουροι follows the contours of other aspects of identity more frequently invoked by Homer (and found among both Trojan and Akhaian forces): πόλις and military contingent.

claims.claim_text: Members of a single polis speak the same language, but barriers may arise between poleis
claims.verbatim_quote: It is assumed that all members of a single πόλις community (and consequently the military contingent based upon it) speak the same language, but that language barriers may arise between πόλεις and their associated military bands.

claims.claim_text: Language is not the most important criterion of identity in the Iliad; it is subordinate to place of origin
claims.verbatim_quote: First, language is not the most important criterion of identity; in all three passages it is coupled with, or even subordinate to, place of origin or membership in a particular military retinue.

claims.claim_text: The term barbarophonos applied to Karians indicates strangeness and remoteness, setting them apart from Trojans and other epikouroi
claims.verbatim_quote: the poet is not only, or even primarily, drawing a distinction between the Karians and the Akhaians (or between the Karians and his Greek-speaking audience), but instead is setting the Karians apart as strange and foreign in general, far removed not just from the Akhaians but also from the Trojans themselves and perhaps even from the other ἐπίκουροι.

claims.claim_text: Barbarophonos does not denote specifically non-Greek speech but strange speech more generally
claims.verbatim_quote: It is likely that the adjective βαρβαρόφωνος here does not denote merely non-Greek (or, more properly, non-Akhaian) speech, but instead carries the force of strange speech more generally

claims.claim_text: The later categorical Greek-Barbarian dichotomy has not yet emerged in the Iliad
claims.verbatim_quote: nor does it appear that the later, categorical Greek-Barbarian dichotomy has yet emerged... The monolithic 'barbarian,' a genus diametrically opposed to 'Greek,' remains absent, awaiting the psychological and cultural upheaval triggered by the Persian Wars.

claims.claim_text: Linguistic unity of Akhaians versus diversity of Trojans represents a contrast between order and chaos
claims.verbatim_quote: the Akhaian unity of language, versus the Trojan-allied disunity, is a contrast between Trojan clamor and chaos on the one hand and Akhaian cohesion and order on the other.

claims.claim_text: No language barrier separates Akhaians from Trojans in the epics; heroes communicate freely
claims.verbatim_quote: Furthermore, never in the Iliad is there a language barrier between Akhaian and Trojan; heroes from both camps freely communicate in face-to-face encounters.

claims.claim_text: The Akhaians display linguistic unity while the Trojans and allies display diversity, indicating Akhaian success at community building
claims.verbatim_quote: Taken in this light, the linguistic unity of the Akhaians is one sign of their success at community building; the babble and clamor of the Trojans a mark of their failure.

claims.claim_text: The Odyssey uses linguistic diversity on Krete to evoke exoticism and strangeness
claims.verbatim_quote: In this case, ethno-linguistic diversity would make Krete strange and distant, perhaps even 'foreign,' despite the fact that the island is ruled by an Akhaian king and sent a contingent to the Trojan War.

claims.claim_text: In early epic, linguistic difference indicates strangeness, distance, and alterity
claims.verbatim_quote: In the Odyssey and in the Theogony, and sometimes in the Iliad, the speaking of a strange language indicates just that, strangeness, difference, and distance.

claims.claim_text: Epic poetry uses language to explore the division between human and divine through different names
claims.verbatim_quote: The contrast between the human and the divine, a recurrent theme in the epic tradition, manifests itself through the allocation of different names to the same creature or place by men on the one hand and gods on the other.

claims.claim_text: The Hymn to Delian Apollo presupposes human linguistic diversity as basis for the miracle of universal understanding
claims.verbatim_quote: in any case, the θαῦμα of the scene presupposes and requires human linguistic diversity.

claims.claim_text: The Hymn to Aphrodite mirrors the Iliad's pattern of linguistic division between Trojans and epikouroi
claims.verbatim_quote: the Homeric Hymn to Aphrodite mirrors the patterns of linguistic division between Trojan and ἐπίκουρος in the Iliad

claims.claim_text: The image of linguistic diversity among Trojan epikouroi had solidified within the epic tradition
claims.verbatim_quote: the poet's need to provide a Phrygian princess with a Trojan education in order to explain how she can converse with Ankhises illustrates the degree to which the image of linguistic diversity among the ἐπίκουροι of the Trojans found in the Iliad had solidified within the epic tradition.

claims.claim_text: In Classical Greece, language was central to Panhellenism as one of three defining elements of Hellenic identity
claims.verbatim_quote: In the Classical Era, language was central to Panhellenism. Herodotus considers speaking a single tongue to be one of the three central elements of Hellenic identity, along with shared customs and a common religion.

claims.claim_text: The Iliad substantially preserves versions current during the late eighth century BCE
claims.verbatim_quote: I believe, however, that the poems as we have them substantially preserve versions current during the late eighth century, with the Iliad perhaps somewhat earlier than the Odyssey.

claims.claim_text: Linguistic arrangements in the Iliad reflect conditions around the time of stabilisation circa 700 BCE
claims.verbatim_quote: Thus, linguistic arrangements in the Iliad likely reflect the present of poet and audience around the time of stabilization, shaped by contemporary conditions, needs, and ideas.

claims.claim_text: Oral tradition retains abstractions like group identity only when relevant to contemporary audience
claims.verbatim_quote: oral tradition only tends to retain information about institutions and relationships so long as they are immediately relevant to the poet's audience or relate directly to contemporary social structures.

claims.claim_text: The Iliad reveals a nascent, non-oppositional Panhellenism based on Akhaian linguistic unity versus Trojan epikouroi diversity
claims.verbatim_quote: Although the Iliad lacks a clearly oppositional Panhellenic identity with consistent differentiation between 'Akhaian-speakers' and others, it contains a nascent Panhellenic identity based on linguistic unity, a recognition of Akhaian homogeneity of language against the linguistic diversity of the Trojan ἐπίκουροι.

claims.claim_text: Panhellenism in the Iliad represents 'us' versus a diverse plural 'those others' rather than unified 'us' versus unified 'them'
claims.verbatim_quote: the development of Panhellenism has been captured at the stage of an operationally but incompletely unified 'us' versus a diverse, plural 'those others.'

claims.claim_text: Eighth-century Greeks found linguistically homogeneous Akhaians familiar and saw an idealisation of their own emergent shared culture
claims.verbatim_quote: the audience found the linguistically homogenous Akhaians familiar, and perhaps saw an extension or idealization of their own emergent shared culture in the Akhaians' unified cultural, social, and political community.

claims.claim_text: The unity of Akhaians in the Iliad would have been more effective as literary device if it resonated with genuine emerging Panhellenism
claims.verbatim_quote: Considering the instability in oral traditions of abstractions such as group identity, the unity of the Akhaians in the Iliad would have been more effective as a literary device if it resonated with a genuine sense of Panhellenism emerging among poet and audience in the eighth century B.C.E.

claims.claim_text: The Trojans are not represented as an undifferentiated barbarian horde; linguistic diversity among epikouroi is neither ignored nor suppressed
claims.verbatim_quote: Nor are the Trojans represented merely as some undifferentiated barbarian horde. Indeed, linguistic diversity among the Trojan ἐπίκουροι is neither ignored nor suppressed, and every reference to variation in language occurs within the Trojan sphere.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The consistency of linguistic patterns across passages indicates deliberate poetic choice rather than accident
trigger_text: the instances of linguistic diversity that do occur in the Iliad follow a consistent pattern
the epics are very consistent in this regard
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The author treats consistency as evidence of intentionality without explicitly arguing that consistent patterns necessarily indicate deliberate authorial choice rather than inherited tradition or coincidence.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The audience of the Iliad around 700 BCE would have understood Akhaians as representing Greeks
trigger_text: the Akhaians—who were certainly viewed as Greek, even if the Trojans had not yet become stand-ins for the generic, undifferentiated barbarian
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The author assumes eighth-century audiences identified Akhaians with Greeks without providing direct evidence for how audiences understood this relationship.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Literary devices are more effective when they resonate with audience beliefs and contemporary social conditions
trigger_text: the unity of the Akhaians in the Iliad would have been more effective as a literary device if it resonated with a genuine sense of Panhellenism emerging among poet and audience
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The argument from literary effectiveness to historical reality requires the unstated premise that effective literary devices necessarily reflect rather than create audience beliefs.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The absence of linguistic diversity among Akhaians is as significant as its presence among Trojans
trigger_text: While linguistic diversity is emphasized among the ἐπίκουροι defending Troy, it is entirely absent from the Akhaian force besieging the city
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The author treats silence (absence of linguistic diversity among Akhaians) as positive evidence for unity, assuming that absence of mention implies presence of uniformity rather than mere lack of interest.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Patterns in the Homeric Hymns and Hesiod illuminate the Iliad because they share a common epic tradition
trigger_text: The nature and importance of these passages can be better assessed by interpreting them in the context of the surviving body of early Greek epic poetry
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The author assumes without defending that Homeric Hymns and other early epic share enough tradition with the Iliad to be mutually illuminating for understanding linguistic patterns.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Free communication between Akhaians and Trojans indicates a shared language or poetic convention ignoring barriers
trigger_text: Akhaians and Trojans communicate freely with one another; no hard linguistic dividing line between Akhaians and others emerges
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The observation that characters communicate freely implies either a shared language in the epic world or a convention ignoring barriers between protagonists, without stating which.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The Persian Wars represent the watershed moment when the Greek-Barbarian dichotomy emerged
trigger_text: The monolithic 'barbarian,' a genus diametrically opposed to 'Greek,' remains absent, awaiting the psychological and cultural upheaval triggered by the Persian Wars
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The author accepts the scholarly consensus that the Persian Wars created oppositional Greek identity as a periodisation marker without independently defending it.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The epic tradition was stable enough by the seventh century that patterns established in the Iliad would be maintained in later works
trigger_text: the poet's need to provide a Phrygian princess with a Trojan education in order to explain how she can converse with Ankhises illustrates the degree to which the image of linguistic diversity among the ἐπίκουροι of the Trojans found in the Iliad had solidified within the epic tradition
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The argument assumes the Hymn to Aphrodite post-dates and deliberately conforms to patterns established in the Iliad, implying stable transmission without proving temporal sequence or intentional conformity.

research_designs.design_description: Close reading of ancient Greek texts to identify and analyse patterns in linguistic representation, comparing treatment across multiple works within the epic tradition
research_designs.design_rationale: Appropriate for investigating cultural attitudes embedded in literary texts where direct historical evidence is unavailable

research_designs.design_description: Systematic comparison of linguistic patterns across Iliad, Odyssey, Theogony, and Homeric Hymns to contextualise findings within broader epic tradition
research_designs.design_rationale: Places individual textual observations in context of genre conventions and tradition

methods.method_name: Close reading with Greek text analysis
methods.method_description: Detailed examination of Greek vocabulary, grammar, and usage in key passages addressing linguistic diversity, with attention to word choice and semantic range
methods.method_rationale: Enables precise analysis of how ancient authors expressed concepts of linguistic identity

methods.method_description: Application of theoretical models of oral tradition transmission (citing Vansina, Morris, Donlan) to interpret stability and change in epic content
methods.method_rationale: Provides interpretive framework for understanding how epic content relates to historical conditions

methods.method_description: Integration of secondary scholarship on dating, Panhellenism, and ethnic identity to contextualise primary textual analysis
methods.method_rationale: Situates argument within ongoing scholarly debates about early Greek identity

data_availability.access_conditions: Primary sources (Homer, Hesiod, Homeric Hymns) are publicly available ancient texts

pass0_metadata.notes: Single-author philological analysis paper. Metadata extracted from JSTOR header. University of New South Wales affiliation noted at end of article.

extraction_notes.pass1_notes: Liberal extraction from interpretive philology paper. 21 evidence items extracted: 16 primary source textual citations from Homer (Iliad, Odyssey), Hesiod (Theogony), and Homeric Hymns; 5 secondary source citations. 26 claims extracted spanning core thesis, methodological arguments, and interpretive claims. 8 implicit arguments identified covering assumptions about audience reception, methodological premises, and bridging claims.
extraction_notes.pass2_notes: Rationalisation pass complete. No consolidations required - items appropriately granular. Added claims C024-C026 for completeness on eighth-century reception and Trojan representation. Final evidence: 21, claims: 26, implicit_arguments: 8. All relationships verified bidirectionally.
extraction_notes.section_extracted: Full paper (pp. 299-316), no formal sections - processed by ~1000-word thematic chunks

Evidence consists of textual observations and scholarly citations rather than measurements
